> There's no simple way using the existing Bitcoin client for participants to figure out the public keys of their addresses without this feature.

Uhhh.  verifyaddress

Why do you think that we'd have createmultisig and addmultisigaddress without a way to do this?
Argh, I didn't realize that command gave the pubkey. I was really wondering why it seemed like bitcoin didn't appear to have a way to do that. Disregard this.\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/df2b175fe3819f47563ed47b4965326fa5217805 for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu
Well, you have my respect for sending a patch instead of just complaining. ... though, sometimes just complaining can be more time efficient!\n
Ha, this caught me unaware once as well. We should add a developer warning :) Having validateaddress sneakily interface with the wallet and return the public key is not really intuitive.\n
`validateaddress` does not make it clear that this is the way you can obtain a public key for an address. I would prefer to have a separate command for obtaining the public key.\n
Yes, there are plans to introduce a `getaddressinfo` command instead.\n`validateaddress` could then eventually return to its prior use, validating addresses without any dependency on the wallet.\n
